channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.

item.title: Flexible Ag<sub>2</sub>Se-based thin-film thermoelectrics for sustainable energy harvesting and cooling
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 15 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62336-2

Here the authors report a low-cost method to fabricate flexible Ag2Se thermoelectric films with high performance and durability, enabling efficient energy harvesting and cooling in wearable and portable thermoelectric devices.
item.dc:title: Flexible Ag<sub>2</sub>Se-based thin-film thermoelectrics for sustainable energy harvesting and cooling

item.title: Publisher Correction: A sodium superionic chloride electrolyte driven by paddle wheel mechanism for solid state batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 14 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62939-9

Publisher Correction: A sodium superionic chloride electrolyte driven by paddle wheel mechanism for solid state batteries

item.title: Halogen substitution strategy of spacer cations in two-dimensional perovskite ferroelectrics gives giant anomalous photovoltaic effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 14 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62903-7

The regulation of ferroelectric photovoltaic properties has been challenging. Here, authors substitute the p-site of cations with halogen for tuning distortion degree of inorganic layer and electric dipole moment of aromatic spacer, achieving ferroelectric anomalous photovoltaic effect of 38.2 V.
item.dc:title: Halogen substitution strategy of spacer cations in two-dimensional perovskite ferroelectrics gives giant anomalous photovoltaic effect
item.dc:creator: Wenjing Li
Yu Ma
